text: Hi, is it possible to setup a redirect on a website based on the user language? For example if I have the browser in italian I will be redirected to <http://mysite.com/it|mysite.com/it>, if I have the browser in english I will be redirected to <http://mysite.com/en|mysite.com/en>
<@UBKP9GNBH> have you tried this:<https://www.askapache.com/htaccess/modrewrite-tips-tricks/#Setting_language_variable_based_Client>?

:wave: Hi, I'm a PM here at HubSpot working on our local development tooling and I would love to connect with you on ways we can improve that experience.  Would you like to share your feedback and let me pick your brain a bit?  Do you have 30 (really ~15) minutes free on Friday between 10 - 1 (EDT) or Monday 11 - 4 (EDT)?  Drop me a DM.  I'd love to chat!

Tagging a few folks I've recently talked to about this - <@U26BLKGE4> <@U7SL518D6> <@U7W5SDG3D> <@UAX5LJ9K3> <@U7ADCU3BM> <@U7W3EP1A6> <@UCBDLK6SU>
but it is possible to do it in HubSpot?
What does everyone use for progrress bar indicators on their pages? For example the progress bar at the top of HS's blogs that shows how long is left on the article when scrolling

haven’t implemented a scrolling indicator myself yet but <https://css-tricks.com/reading-position-indicator/>

I’ve also seen one that was pure css, don’t know where that was though unfortunately
Yea i came across that one and this one: <https://github.com/mburakerman/prognroll>
that one certainly looks simple enough to implement
<http://leightoninteractive-2626246.hs-sites.com/blog-5/blog-post-6> - i pretty much cloned the HS blog. did the progress bar with some basic CSS and a little bit of custom JS.
<@UA6LDL887> <@U88H3MTFW> <@UBAJRD7UN>
thanks <@U22PKFRU5>

This codepen is amazing
<https://codepen.io/blucube/pen/bdGgzg>
might be good for pillar pages
anyone know of a way to add default content for a new blog post?

no idea but if you figure it out I’d love to default posts to bacon ipsum for one of my clients.
<https://baconipsum.com/>
You could just set that up as a custom module instead of the default blog content module
Anyone else see this great news? <https://www.HubSpot.com/product-updates/themes-in-forms>
glad to see the blue buttons are finally going the way of the dodo!
My plan exactly
Was really more excited about the Style raw html at the end. I’ve had a few instances where I have to fight the CMS just to get a form styled.
<@UDC5GRX6E> belch looks cool though

`These themes are applied on a form by form basis and will only affect forms that are embedded externally or used in a standalone URL.`

Looks like they’re saying it only happens with the js embed, if you use the hubl embed it might not have that feature.
can someone confirm pls: I know HS sets a cookie when a user fills out a form. Doesn't it also set a cookie when a link is clicked in an email we send from HS?
no, it’s not physically possible to set a cookie from an email. the closest thing would be to set it on the recipient page once the user hits that page. that could be flawed though
ok so solely on form submit. got it, thanks
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/email-tracking/how-does-HubSpot-sales-email-tracking-work>

>HubSpot Sales is able to track email opens by embedding a one pixel invisible image into the message once it is sent. Links are tracked by appending tracking to the end of any hyperlink that is present within your email.
Maybe I should have rephrased that. What I'm trying to confirm is whether we can _identify_ a previously unknown user after they click a link in an email we send from HS
well you have to “know” them to send an email to them, so i mean you could just have a link with a query param that is generated by the contact’s name or id
Maybe I'm missing something but how would they be unknown if you are launching an email to them?
lol <@U7SL518D6>
I’m all about them query params. use em rediculously :stuck_out_tongue:

i mean unknown as far as the tracking code. basically we have a form, right, that we'd like to pre-populate if at all possible. but if say someone comes and they're anonymous, but they _know_ they've filled this out before (maybe on another computer) we have an email address field where they can put in their email. HS then sends them a link to essentially the same page, but now that they've received and opened that email from HS, we have their info, and the form is populated.

so wait what’s the problem here?

You DONT want the form prepopulated?
only once we "confirm" the email by sending them a link

Okay think i get it now:
User fills out the form
You dont want it to pre-populate the form(if the visitor hits that page again) until after the user has gotten the email and came back.
how about this. have a query param in your email link like ?formvisible  and in your page if that query param is there render the form
otherwise the form is not there

Let me be more specific. This is a mailing address change form.
1. User goes to the page with the form. If we don't see the cookie, we show a HS form with just an email address field. That form fires off a workflow that sends an email saying, "Click Here to Update Your Address" - the assumption being the clicking of that link would now identify them in their browser, and we then display the form, populated with their info
2. This almost works. However the user is identified immediately after submitting the form. So just a page refresh populates the form, which we don't want. We are thinking of just having our own form, not a HS form, submit to the HS form through the API to avoid setting the cookie at that stage
that sounds like a lot of extra work for no reason. just disable the prepopulation on that form and use query params to populate the fields from the email

if you toggle off the prepopulate feature it just removes the field population based on the cookie. it wont affect the query param method. thus solving your problem the user could refresh all day and it wouldn’t populate the form, they’d have to go through the email to have it pre-populate

but again similar question. why even show the same form still if the intent is to show different fields when they come back from the email?

I’d think you’d have 2 forms, and you just use a query param that you have in the link from the email which then toggles the display of the second form(the one with the additional fields)
Maybe someone knows a better way but afaik you would have to use a third party service for that.
Hi <@UDATKECAD>. We have a CMS Membership capability currently in beta. It requires Marketing Hub Enterprise, but if you're interested let <@U5SGFUU80> or myself know.

Essentially the "CMS Membership" capability enables you to set a list within HubSpot to control access to a page. Once that's done users on the list can create a unique login and password to view the content.
Very exciting!
If you're looking for an option though that does not require Marketing Hub Enterprise, it would require a third-party tool.
Finally, I've been waiting for these changes!!!!
I have mixed feelings on this. expecting clients to break their forms then tell me to fix them #jobSecurityIsntAlwaysFun
What kind of third party service would you prefer Pete?
I mentioned this in a different chat Diana and I were having... but here's one option via oAuth: <http://booya.inboundlabs.co/>
I don’t have a go-to, looks like Luke posted one in the thread. Generally when I’ve done them the client has had some proprietary member area.

first off, thanks for the input, i do appreciate your time. i think you're right and we've approached this wrongly. is the query param method an actual HubSpot option/thing, or simply a matter of us writing code to pull the params and fill the fields?
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/KCS_Article/Forms/Can-I-auto-populate-form-fields-through-a-query-string>
ok, got it, thanks again
Hi guys! Here to help! Monday at 11 EDT could be good for me. I'm from Italy and it will be 5pm here
